My community conducts a citizen satisfaction survey every few years that has some QOL questions. It is a phone survey so the questions are worded as a script. The past surveys are available on our website: http://goodyearaz.gov/index.aspx?NID=374

answers.author: Damema Mann
answers.text:
Relying on opt-in Web surveys leaves jurisdictions with a limited number of respondents who are unlikely to be representative of the entire community. Thinking about how you’d like to use survey results, you’ll want to consider the difference between being able to say, “These results tell you what these specific residents think,” compared to being able to say, “These results come from a scientific survey and tell you what all adults in my community think, within a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.” Generally, scientific surveys are used for budgeting, planning and monitoring policy and program changes and their use has grown by more than ten fold over the last couple of decades. Hope this helps.

author: Rachel Leininger
text:
My community is interested in conducting a Quality of Life Survey.  Have any other communities conducted a QOL Survey?  What types of questions did you ask?  Any insight would be helpful!
We hope to use Survey Monkey to distribute and collect responses.  If anyone would be willing to share a similar survey that would be great.  Thanks!
